subject: Re: [junit] limited access to data
msgSnippet: ... I happen to have a similar situation, there s no easy to reset the database to a specific known good configuration and ensure that it s in that state I
messageBody:
On Tue, 2003-07-29 at 14:20, Ostermueller, Erik wrote:
> Hello, all.
>
> This post isn't necessarily JUnit related,
> but it is very unit-testing related.
>
> With our legacy mainframe system,
> it is not possible to add or
> delete data on the fly (ie, from a unit test) -- you have to rely on
> nightly batch processes for this.
>
> Since the unit tests can't set up and tear down
> their own data, we're running into lots of snags.
>
> Have you all encountered similar situations?
> How have you worked with or worked around them?
>
> Thanks for letting me cry on your shoulder,
>
> Erik Ostermueller
>

I happen to have a similar situation, there's no easy to reset the
database to a specific known good configuration and ensure that it's in
that state I need when I run my tests. When I shared this situation and
my different ideas of how to deal with it, the suggestions I got all
centered on one method of handling it: abstract the unmanageable behind
interfaces and run my tests using a MockObject implementation of those
interfaces.

In your case is the mainframe specific code abstracted out of the
testable functionality? If so you can test using a Mock implementation
of the mainframe. The other side someone else already suggested which
is to ensure that the generated batch code matches known good examples.
Simply set up the fake data which would generate one of your known good
examples, and run the code in a unit test and check the output in the
testFunction().

Good Luck!
I know it's not easy to do all of this in my job. But it's worth it
where you can.
